A scheme was evolved for the erection of different types of houses, and specimen homes were shown in different parts of England. I saw one of these demonstration houses myself in London, and it was stated in the House of Commons that they could be constructed in large numbers at a very much less cost than brick houses could be. I quite admit that it was the intention of that scheme to get a large number of houses built very quickly, and that it was the dearth of labour for brick houses that led the Government to adopt this particular idea. But it, might be advisable to investigate the possibility of constructing houses of several types in Australia. If we adopt a housing scheme it is surely, in part at any rate, because there are people here urgently in need of houses. I ask the committee to consider whether it might not be possible for other types of houses to be constructed in Australia at a smaller cost, and in greater numbers, than at present.
- Is that not a matter for the State housing authorities to consider ?

- It is, at any rate, for us to suggest it. This is a Commonwealth housing scheme .and it is just as appropriate for us to suggest methods and types of buildings to the State authorities as to lay down the amount or percentage to be advanced on land, and the cost of the dwelling to be erected. Speaking in the House of Commons on the 16th December, 1924, Mr. Neville Chamberlain said this -

quote.para: Last week I paid a special visit to Glasgow in order to see for myself what was being don? in this direction by Lord Weir and by others who ave designing and building houses of different types, and I came back feeling very hopeful of the future, after what I had seen.

The idea of steel houses comes strange to many people, and especially perhaps to those who. have never seen one. and who imagine it as a sort of petrol tin, hideous to look at, and uncomfortable to live in, but I do not think, if they saw the houses I saw in Glasgow, they would maintain that view at all. Indeed, as far as the house constructed by Lord Weir is concerned, it is a misnomer to call it a steel house. It is really a house constructed with a timber frame, lined with steel plates, upon the outside, and upon the inside with a material which I think is composed of compressed wood pulp and asbestos, but which looks rather like' smooth brown cardboard.

speech.para: Subsequently Mr. Chamberlain said that the cost of the houses would to some extent depend upon the quantity ordered. A year later he made another speech in the House in which he gave the result of the efforts made to achieve success in providing houses on a big scale. He said -

quote.para: I agree in the main with the honorable gentleman who said that the idea of demonstration houses had been a failure. I saw one of the houses : the type is very attractive, but I dare say it would need slight alterations, to make it suitable to the heat of the Australian climate. Mr. Chamberlain went on to say -

But why has it been a failure? It has been a failure because the building industry has deliberately set itself against the adoption even of demonstration houses, and they have gone so far as to threaten any local authority which put up even a pair of houses - so that people might see what it was which was being, offered - that the whole labour would be taken off in houses of any other type. ... I think if it had not been for the opposition of the trade unions and the building industry, and the employers as well, these demonstration houses would have been erected in a great number of places; and I think that once people had seen the kind of thing they were they would have insisted upon having them.

speech.para: It is arguable that it would be better to have more houses of cheaper construction than fewer houses of a better type. At any rate, that point should be given every consideration. When speaking on the great housing achievement of Great Britain, the Treasurer mentioned that to the enid of December, 1926, 411,791 houses had been built under various British schemes. According to the House of Commons Hansard of 10th May last, the houses completed in Great Britain with government assistance, from 1919 to March, 1927, numbered 545, 2S7. The clause opens up also the subject of second mortgages. As I understand it, one of the purposes of the bill is to provide for advances to a considerable percentage of the value of the property to exclude the possibility of a second mortgage being required. In his second-reading speech the Treasurer said that where the rate of interest on a first mortgage was 6 or 7 per cent., rates of from 9 to 12 per cent, on second mortgages were excessive. I do not agree with him. The second mortgagee has very poor security for his money, and it is not unreasonable that he should have a proportionately high rate of interest. Bates of from 9 to 12 per cent, are, therefore, not too high on second mortgages. In any case, the possibility of the presence of the second mortgagee cannot be avoided in any housing scheme unless the amount of the advance is 100 pei1 cent, of the value of the property. It is useless, therefore, to advance the argument that 90 per cent, of the valuation should be lent to the home builder in order to save him from raising a second mortgage, and the question is narrowed down to the simple issue whether 90 per cent, should be advanced on a particular house. At the present time, as honorable members know, there is a considerable shortage of money for investment, and values of city properties are high. I think the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory) will agree with me that there is every prospect in the not very distant future of a slump in city values. Of course, under this bill, the risk will fall upon the State authorities; but, nevertheless, it is undesirable for this Parliament to declare that 90 per cent, is a proper proportion of the value of a property to lend to a home builder, or to indicate to the State authorities that they may advance to that amount. The ordinary trustee can advance up to 66 per cent.

talk.start.para: - The limit is 60 per cent, in Victoria.

- I know that it is more arguable that 90 per cent, should be loaned on a house worth 1,000 than that that advance should be made on one worth 2,000, but even in the former case it means that another 100 has to be found by the borrower from his own available cash or through a second mortgage. In these days of high wages, the unmarried man on the basic wage, which is based on what is necessary to keep a married man, his wife and three children, may quite reasonably be expected to save something towards getting a house for himself when he marries. That is the time when a man would usually require assistance under a housing scheme. To my mind, it would be wise to limit, not only the percentage which may be loaned, but also the maximum which may be advanced. In this respect. I think we ought to be guided by what is done in other parts of the world. Notwithstanding his quotations of what has been accomplished in Great Britain and on the continent as well as in the various States of Australia, the Treasurer has not suggested that in any part of the world a maximum advance of 1,800 is provided for in any housing scheme. That fact should make us pause. Is Australia so prosperous that we can afford to make advances up to 90 per cent. on a maximum value which is 50 per cent. higher than the maximum in Great Britain ? I think the maximum in Great Britain is 1,200. In order to test the' matter. I move -

quote.para: That the word "eight," paragraph (a), subparagraph (ii) be omitted, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the word " five."

speech.para: The limit of 1,500 I propose is nearly double the maximum amount provided for in the legislation of any Australian State. Subsequently, I shall move to limit the percentage from 90 per cent. to 80 per cent.

talk.start.para: .- There is no State Savings Bank in Tasmania, but there are two institutions which are really public institutions, one operating in Hobart and the other in Launceston. I am afraid that we may have in connexion with the allocation of money under this bill a repetition of what occurred some time ago when the State of Tasmania made money available in connexion with the agricultural bank. On the first morning after it was known that an amount of 50,000 was available for advances, the whole of the money was applied for and absorbed in Hobart, the other portions of the State getting none of it. I suggest that the Treasurer should make provision for this money to be allocated on, say, an electorate basis. I am in favour of the amount of the advance being reduced to 1,500, but I do not see eye to eye with the honorable member for Boothby (Mr. Duncan-Hughes) as to the proportion of the advance being reduced from 90 per cent. to80 per cent.

talk.start.para: .- I move -

quote.para: That after paragraph (a), sub-paragraph (iii), the following sub-paragraph be inserted : - " (iv) by providing for the purchase or construction by the authority of buildings to be let by the authority as tenements or flats; and "

speech.para: As the scheme stands it meets only the needs of those who have not purchased and are unable to purchase a house. It deals only with the outer and newer suburbs-, I desire the scheme to be made applicable to the older and more crowded areas. At present, in Sydney and Melbourne in particular, thousands of families are living under the worst housing conditions in Australia. They are overcrowded, their conditions are in-' sanitary, and their children are growing up under altogether unfavorable auspices. A Commonwealth housing scheme should cover these areas. I regard this as only . a partial scheme. It provides for the erection of freehold detached cottages, but altogether overlooks the claims of those who reside in the congested inner suburbs of big cities, where land can be purchased only at very high prices. It would be impossible on account of these high prices to buy allotments in these areas for building either detached or semi-detached cottages.I can see no reason why we should not follow the example of many great cities in other parts of the world and resume considerable inner suburban areas for the purpose of erecting on them substantial tenement houses or flats, and of providing parks anil gardens and playgrounds for the children. If such a scheme were applied to these areas, the conditions of life in thom would be entirely changed. I think the Commonwealth Government could very well take up this proposal.

talk.start.para: . - I trust that the honorable member will not press his amendment, for, irrespective of the merits of his proposal, everybody will agree that substantial calls will be made on all the money that will be provided for the purposes already outlined in the bill. We should not add to the calls that may be made upon it.

speech.para: Mr.Bruce. - If any of the State authorities represent, that they desire money to be made available for these purposes, the Government will be prepared to consider the matter.

talk.start.para: .- I support the amendment. Some time ago, at a conference of the South Australian branch of the Australian Labour party, I was successful in having a pious, and perhaps somewhat similar, motion carried to the effect that the States should undertake the building of homes along the lines mentioned by the honorable member for Henty (Mr. Gullett). I do not believe in the private ownership of property. If we could initiate a system. of State ownership of homes for the people, it would be wise for us to do so. There is nothing unusual or even original in this proposal. In various parts of the City of Adelaide cottage homes have been erected for invalid and indigent people. Bight in the centre of the city itself we have what are known as the Elder cottages, which were erected 20 or 30 years ago through the generosity of Sir Thomas Elder, whose name is renowned even to-day for his public spirit and beneficence. These cottages occupy a large block of land having frontages on Angas and Wakefield streets, and even to-day they are eagerly sought after by people in need of homes. Though they have been in occupation for more than twenty years, they are in an excellent state of repair, having been built under the best of conditions. They are convenient and comfortable, and are in no sense whatever slum cottages. The trust which controls thom charges a rental which is sufficient to cover maintenance and depreciation, and the scheme has been an outstanding success. We should be well advised to follow the example which Sir Thomas Elder set so many years ago.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: . - I move -

quote.para: That after paragraph (b), sub-paragraph ( i ) , the following Bub-paragraph bc inserted : - " (iA) A loan is not made for the purpose of discharging a mortgage unless the conditions of the mortgage, or the conditions of any further loans on the property, are, in the opinion of the authority, unduly disadvantageous to the mortgagor."

speech.para: This amendment has been suggested by the savings bank authorities for the purpose of ensuring that the funds that may be made available under this bill shall be dealt with in such a way that the utmost benefit will follow the expenditure. It is felt that it would not be desirable to make large inroads into the funds simply for the purpose of discharging mortgages at, say, 7 per cent., and so saving only about per cent. to the individuals concerned, when by so doing other persons would be prevented from obtaining advances to buy or build homes. The- object of the amendment is to ensure that the greatest good shall be done for the greatest number, rather than that an almost insignificant measure of relief shall be granted to a few individuals.
